T1129.long: The Windows module loader can be instructed to load DLLs from arbitrary local paths and arbitrary Universal Naming Convention (UNC) network paths. This functionality resides in NTDLL.dll and is part of the Windows Native API which is called from functions like CreateProcess(), LoadLibrary(), etc. of the Win32 API.

T1053.long: Utilities such as at and schtasks, along with the Windows Task Scheduler, can be used to schedule programs or scripts to be executed at a date and time. A task can also be scheduled on a remote system, provided the proper authentication is met to use RPC and file and printer sharing is turned on. Scheduling a task on a remote system typically required being a member of the Administrators group on the the remote system.

get.description:
Get a subset of Constraint Profiles restricted by page, per_page, and filter.
The returned profiles can be filtered by one or more attributes.
The basic syntax is: attribute attribute_operator "value" or attribute in ("value1", "value2") for "in" attribute operator.
  • Supported attributes (case-sensitive): id, name, status, values, description
  • Supported attribute operators: eq (equal: case-sensitive fully match), in(in array of strings, limited to 10 strings: case-sensitive fully match), like (contains: case-insensitive partial match).
  • Supported value type: string, which must be enclosed with double quotes.
    • Examples:
    1. Find a profile name contains "eng": ?filter=name like "%eng%".
    2. Find a profile status in "update" or "delete": ?filter=modify_type in ("update").
    3. Find profiles whose id is ID1 or ID2 or ID3: ?filter=id in ("ID1","ID2","ID3").
    4. Find profiles whose values equal "www.netskope.com": ?filter=values eq "www.netskope.com".

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Specifying fields to be returned in the response. Example: ?fields=profile_name,profile_data,device_data,variable,modify_by,modify_type,modify_time. Note that the profile_id field will always be returned. If omitted, all fields will be returned.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The (zero-based) page of the first item in the list to retrieve. Default to 0.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: Max number of items to retrieve. Default to 100. Maximum 1000.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description: Filter returned profiles. See description for full example.

parameters.name: sortby
parameters.description: Sort lists of constraints profiles by a field. Default sort by name field.

parameters.name: sortorder
parameters.description: Assign sorting order with ascending or descending

get.description:
Get alert events with the ability to filter the output based on attribute parameters.

This endpoint is intended to be used for ad-hoc query and allows users to get the alert events in the system by providing various parameters in the request. Users can use this endpoint to filter and retrieve all and/or specific alert events based on criteria like alert_name, alert_type, time range and other relevant metadata.

For example, to filter alerts to only show total count of alerts for a specific duration: `?starttime=1731535136&endtime=1736805536&fields=count_total:count(id)`
You can also filter on multiple attributes by adding an `and` logical operator and another attribute in the same format as the previous example. For example, to show total alert count for app equals Facebook: `?query=app eq 'Facebook' and alert_type eq 'policy'`

Additional examples can be found here:

For SIEM ingestion, please consider using the `api/v2/dataexport` endpoints which are explained here:

parameters.name: endtime

get.description:
Get application events with the ability to filter the output based on attribute parameters.

This endpoint is intended to be used for ad-hoc query and allows users to get the application events in the system by providing various parameters in the request. Users can use this endpoint to filter and retrieve all and/or specific application events based on criteria like app, appcategory, time range and other relevant metadata.

For example, to filter alerts to only show total count of applications for a specific duration: `?starttime=1731535136&endtime=1736805536&fields=count_total:count(id)`
You can also filter on multiple attributes by adding an `and` logical operator and another attribute in the same format as the previous example. For example, to show total alert count for app equals Facebook: `?query=appcategory eq 'Cloud Storage' and app eq 'Microsoft Office'`

Additional examples can be found here:

For SIEM ingestion, please consider using the `api/v2/dataexport` endpoints which are explained here:

parameters.description: Query timeout, in seconds
parameters.name: timeout

parameters.description: JQL query to filter the alerts by
parameters.name: query

parameters.description: Start time, in Unix timestamp, of the desired alerts
parameters.name: starttime

parameters.description: End time, in Unix timestamp, of the desired alerts
parameters.name: endtime

parameters.description: Query offset
parameters.name: offset

parameters.description: Number of results to limit the output by
parameters.name: limit

parameters.description: Number of results to limit the sub-aggregations by
parameters.name: sublimit

parameters.description: Fields to aggregate on
parameters.name: groupbys

parameters.description: Secondary fields to aggregate on
parameters.name: subgroupbys

parameters.description: Fields to sort the results by
parameters.name: orderbys

parameters.description: Names of the columns whose values want to be retrieved in results.
parameters.name: fields

get.description:
Get device status information with the ability to filter the output based on attribute parameters.

This endpoint is intended to be used for ad-hoc query and allows users to get the device status information in the system by providing various parameters in the request. Users can use this endpoint to filter and retrieve all and/or specific device information based on criteria like hostname, device_id, time range and other relevant metadata.

For example, to filter device information to only show total count of device ids for a specific duration: `?starttime=1731535136&endtime=1736805536&fields=count_total:count(device_id)`
You can also filter on multiple attributes by adding an `and` logical operator and another attribute in the same format as the previous example. For example, to show total device count for hostname equals ITE004433: `?starttime=1731535136&endtime=1736805536&fields=count_total:count(device_id)&query=hostname eq 'ITE004433'`

Additional examples can be found here:

get.description:
API returns data for the following PubSubLite metrics: 

 1. subscription/backlog_message_count - Number of messages that have been sent to a subscription but have not yet been acknowledged by any consumer. 

 2. subscription/oldest_unacked_message_age - The age of the oldest unacknowledged message in a subscription i.e. how long the oldest unacknowledged message has been waiting for acknowledgment.

get.description:
<details><summary>**Following operations supported for filtering** 

 Query Format- (column to filter) (oprator) (value to filter)' 

 Present Operator (pr)- does not require a Value to match 

 In Operator Uses Array of Supported Type</summary>

 <summary>**Publisher Filters**</summary>
  | Columns to filter|Operation Supported|Accepted Value Type|
 |- |- |- |
 |`name`|`'eq', 'ne', 'sw', 'has', 'in', 'pr'`|`String`|
 |`common_name` (PublisherCN)|`'eq', 'ne', 'sw', 'has', 'in', 'pr'`|`String`|
 |`status`|`'eq', 'ne', 'sw', 'has', 'in', 'pr'`|`String`|
 |`profile_id` (Update Profile)|`'eq','ne', 'gt','ge','lt','le', 'in', 'pr'`|`Integer`|
 |`nwa_ba`(Browser Access AnyApp)|`'eq'`|`Boolean`|
 |`version`|`'eq', 'ne', 'pr', 'has', 'sw'`|`String`|
 |`upstat` (Version Update Status)|`'eq', 'ne', 'in', 'pr'`|`String`|
 -------------------------------
 

 <summary>**Private App Filters**</summary>
  | Columns to filter|Operation Supported|Accepted Value Type|
 |- |- |- |
 |`name`|`'eq', 'ne', 'sw', 'has', 'in', 'pr'`|`String`|
 |`publisher_name`|`'eq', 'ne', 'sw', 'has', 'in', 'pr'`|`String`|
 |`tag_id`|`'eq','ne', 'gt','ge','lt','le', 'in', 'pr'`|`Integer`|
 |`reachable`|`'eq'`|`yes or no`|
 |`clientless_access` (Browser Access)|`'eq'`|`Boolean`|
 |`use_publisher_dns`|`'eq'`|`Boolean`|
 |`private_app_protocol` (Browser Access Protocol)|`'eq', 'ne', 'sw', 'has', 'in', 'pr'`|`String`|
 |`host`|`'eq', 'ne', 'sw', 'has', 'in', 'pr'`|`String`|
 |`in_policy`|`'eq'`|`yes or no`|
 |`in_steering`|`'eq'`|`yes or no`|
 |`allow_unauthenticated_cors` (CORS Enabled)|`'eq'`|`Boolean`|
 -------------------------------


</details>

get.description:
The NPA Publisher is a software package that enables private application
 connectivity between your data center and the Netskope cloud. It is a crucial
 component of Netskopes Private Access (NPA) solution, which provides zero-trust
 network access (ZTNA) to private applications and data in hybrid IT environments.
 
This endpoint queries and returns all publisher objects.

Features may require additional licensing, please work with account team to enable.

post.description:
Submit url re-categorization requests with the given details.
### Duplicate Url Handling A url is considered duplicate if: * The same url is included in a previous batch and the url in the previous batch is still in an open/on-going status * The same url is already included in the same POST request For cases of duplicate url, the API will return the url id of the previous open url.

**Note** that the urls are normalized when checking for duplicates.
Example: | Original Url | Normalized Url | |-----------------------|----------------| | `http://netskope.com` | `netskope.com` | | `netskope.com/` | `netskope.com` | With the above example, if there's an ongoing re-categorization request for `http://netskope.com` url, the `netskope.com/` url will be considered as duplicate when you try to submit it.
### Url Quota Limit The number of urls for re-categorization is subject to 50 urls per day per tenant limit (default).
You can check your quota limit status using the response's HTTP headers.
``` $ curl -i -X 'POST' $HOST/url/recategorizations -d '{...}' > HTTP/1.1 201 > x-netskope-url-quota-limit: 50 > x-netskope-url-quota-remaining: 9 > x-netskope-url-quota-reset: 1664871531 ```

x-netskope-url-quota-limit.description: The maximum number of urls for recategorization you're allowed to submit per day per tenant.

x-netskope-url-quota-remaining.description: The remaining number of urls for recategorization in the current quota limit window.

x-netskope-url-quota-reset.description: The time in Unix epoch seconds at which the current quota limit window will reset.

get.description:
Get a subset of Custom Categories restricted by offset, limit, and filter.
The returned data can be filtered by one or more attributes (up to 9) using the filter query parameter.
The basic syntax is: attribute attribute_operator "value" or attribute in ("value1", "value2") for "in" attribute operator.
Support multiple attributes AND conjunction filtering by using " and " in the query.
  • Supported attributes (case-sensitive): id, name, status, description, included_predefined_categories, included_url_lists, excluded_url_lists, included_destination_profiles, excluded_destination_profiles
  • Supported attribute operators: eq (equal: case-sensitive fully match), in(in array of strings, limited to 10 strings: case-sensitive fully match), co (contains: case-insensitive partial match).
  • Supported value type: string, which must be enclosed with double quotes.
  • Examples:
    • Find custom categories whose names contain "eng": ?filter=name co "eng".
    • Find custom categories in "pending-create" or "pending-update" status: ?filter=status in ("pending-create","pending-update").
    • Find custom categories whose id is UUID1 or UUID2: ?filter=id in ("UUID1","UUID2").
    • Find custom categories whose name contains "eng" AND status in "pending-update" or "pending-delete": ?filter=name co "eng" and status in ("pending-update","pending-delete").

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Specifying fields to be returned in the response. Example: ?fields=name,description. Note that the id field will always be returned. If omitted, all fields will be returned.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The (zero-based) offset of the first item in the list to retrieve. Default to 0.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Max number of items to retrieve. Default to 10. Maximum 100.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description: Filter returned profiles. See description for full example.

parameters.name: sortby
parameters.description: Sort the list of custom categories by a field. Default sort by name field.

parameters.name: sortorder
parameters.description: Assign sorting order with ascending or descending

get.summary: This API endpoint is restricted to Internal Beta. Get Destination Profiles
get.description:
Get a subset of Destination Profiles restricted by offset, limit, and filter.
The returned profiles can be filtered by one or more attributes.
The basic syntax is: attribute attribute_operator "value" or attribute in ("value1", "value2") for "in" attribute operator.
  • Supported attributes (case-sensitive): id, name, status, values, description
  • Supported attribute operators: eq (equal: case-sensitive fully match), in(in array of strings, limited to 10 strings: case-sensitive fully match), co (contains: case-insensitive partial match).
  • Supported value type: string, which must be enclosed with double quotes.
    • Examples:
    1. Find a profile name contains "eng": ?filter=name co "eng".
    2. Find a profile status in "pending-update" or "pending-delete": ?filter=status in ("pending-update","pending-delete").
    3. Find profiles whose id is ID1 or ID2 or ID3: ?filter=id in ("ID1","ID2","ID3").
    4. Find profiles whose values contains "netskope": ?filter=values co "netskope".
    5. Find profiles whose values equal "www.netskope.com": ?filter=values eq "www.netskope.com".
    6. Find profiles whose values is either "www.netskope.com" or "www.example.com": ?filter=values in ("www.netskope.com","www.example.com").

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Specifying fields to be returned in the response. Example: ?fields=name,description. Note that the id field will always be returned. If omitted, all fields will be returned.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The (zero-based) offset of the first item in the list to retrieve. Default to 0.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Max number of items to retrieve. Default to 10. Maximum 50.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description: Filter returned profiles. See description for full example.

parameters.name: sortby

get.description: Get a subset of DNS Profiles restricted by offset, limit, and filter. The returned profiles can be filtered by one or more attributes.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description:
The basic syntax is:

  1. Attribute operator "Value"
  2. Attribute in ("value1", "value2") for "in" attribute operator.

  1. Supported attributes (case-insensitive): id, name, status, and description.
  2. Supported attribute operators (case-insensitive): eq (equals), sw (starts with), in, and co (contains).
  3. Supported value type (case-insensitive): string, which must be enclosed with double quotes.
  4. Supported logical operators (case-insensitive): and.

For example, to filter returned profiles to only show records with ID in ID1 or ID2 or ID3:
?filter=id in ("ID1","ID2","ID3").


You can also filter multiple attributes by adding an and logical operator and another attribute in the same format as the previous example.


For example, to show records whose name start with "prod" and whose description contain "service":
?filter=name sw "prod" and description co "service".

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Max number of items to retrieve. Default to 10. Maximum 150.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The (zero-based) offset of the first item in the list to retrieve. Default to 0.

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description:
comma separated fields names:

Supported fields: id, name, description, log_traffic, create_time, modify_time, create_by, modify_by, domain_config, tunnel_config, custom_config and status.

parameters.name: sortby
parameters.description:
comma separated fields names:

Supported fields: id, name, create_time, modify_time and status.

parameters.name: sortorder
parameters.description: asc or desc

patch.description: This API allows you to add or remove a static list of applications or IDs to an existing tag, as well as manage the list of applications along with associated rules. **Important points to note:** 1. If **rules** are provided, they will **overwrite** any existing rules. If no previous rules exist, the new rules will be added to the existing tag. 2. If **apps/ids** are provided along **with the rules**, they will **overwrite** all previously associated static applications with the tag. 3. If **apps/ids** are provided **without rules**, the static applications will be added or removed from the tag based on the specified **action** parameter. 4. Use the `**add_apps** and **delete_apps**` parameters to add new apps or remove existing apps from the tag. This applies both with and without rules. 5. The **action** parameter is not applicable when using **add_apps or delete_apps**. 6. It is mandatory to provide either apps, IDs, add_apps, or delete_apps with the tag. 7. **apps/ids** are mutually exclusive with **add_apps/delete_apps**. Note: This is an early access API and subject to change | Request Body Params | Description | |-----------------|-------------| |action | Tag action to be performed, 'append or remove'. Default is 'append' ( Should not be used with predefined tags like Sanctioned, Unsanctioned, Departmental, Enterprise and Consumer ) (Mandatory in case of app tagging & not required in case of attribute rule based tagging). |apps | List of static Application names(current name). 100 is the max allowed input size (Optional if ids/rules/add_apps/delete_apps parameter are not specified).| | ids | List of Application ids. 100 is the max allowed input size (Optional if apps/rules/add_apps/delete_apps parameter are not specified).| | add_apps | List of static application names (current name) to add to the tag. 100 is the max allowed input size (Optional if apps/ids/rules/delete_apps parameter are not specified).| | delete_apps | List of static application names (current name) to be deleted from the tag. 100 is the max allowed input size (Optional if apps/ids/rules/add_apps parameter are not specified).| |description | Description of the tag (Optional & it is applicable only for attribute rule based tagging).| |rules | List of rules with attribute, condition & value (Mandatory in case of attribute rule based tagging).| |delete_all_rules | Used to delete all the rules from the specified tag which can take value as 1/true (optional & it is applicable only with add_apps/delete_apps or both).|

parameters.description: Existing tag to be added to the list of applications/ids.
parameters.name: tag

value.message: Tag updated successfully to the list of apps/ids

add_apps/delete_apps Response.description: Response with only add_apps / delete_apps or both.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Custom classifier ID

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: offset of a large result, default to 0

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Batch size of each result, default to 0. If no 'limit' is provided or a 0 value is given, the full list is returned.

parameters.name: folderPrefix
parameters.description: This is the case-sensitive filtering folder used for narrowing down the valid files. It has to be the full path prefix meaning if you're getting files under  'folder2' under root 'folder1', the query needs to be 'folderPrefix=/folder1/folder2/'

parameters.name: fileSig
parameters.description: This is the case-sensitive filtering string for any valid file. This call could be slow since it will go through all the files for a given classifier.  'fileSig=xyz', will match '/folder1/folder2/abcxyz.jpg'.  'fileSig=folder2' will match '/folder1/folder2/abcxyz.jpg'.

parameters.name: status
parameters.description: This parameter checks for file status. Currently only 'valid' or 'invalid' are allowed status values.

parameters.name: category
parameters.description: This optional parameter indicates the category of the file. Currently only 'positive' or 'negative' are allowed category values. If parameter is missing, both positive and negative files are returned

parameters.name: isOutlier
parameters.description: This optional boolean parameter checks whether the file is an outlier. An outlier is a file that's not similar enough to the rest of the files in the training set. When not provided, both results will be returned.

parameters.name: sort
parameters.description: This optional parameter specify how the results should be sorted. Choices are: 'updateAsc', 'updateDesc', 'pathAsc', 'pathDesc' where 'Asc/Desc' means ascending/descending order so 'sort=updateAsc' means sort by update time in ascending order. Default is 'updateDesc' meaning result is sorted by latest records on the top.

parameters.name: sessionend

connectivity between your data center and the Netskope cloud. It is a crucial
component of Netskopes Private Access (NPA) solution, which provides zero-trust
network access (ZTNA) to private applications and data in hybrid IT environments.

This resource updates bulk updates publishers to an upgrade profile.

frequency.description:

 minute (059) \
  hour (023) \
    day of the month (131) \
    month (112) (Leave as *) \
     day of the week (MON, TUE, WED, THU, FRI, SAT, SUN) \
0 0 1 * TUE => (Midnight, Weekly, Tuesday)

`api/v2/infrastructure/publishers/releases`

Please see enum for accepted values.

transaction_events_metrics_200.description:
1.Transaction events metrics data per metric type. 

2. API will return hourly buckets equivalent to hours parameter value. Default value is 24 Hours, Maximum Value is one week: 168 Hours. 

 3. Time Series buckets maintains the ascending order i.e. latest hour data will be the last data point.

subscription/backlog_message_count.description:
1. Number of messages that have been sent to a subscription but have not yet been acknowledged by any consumer. 

2. Results are further categorized per partition number. 

3. Each partition results are hourly buckets in the ascending order. 

4. Value is number of unacknowledged messages.

subscription/oldest_unacked_message_age.description:
1. The age of the oldest unacknowledged message in a subscription. 

2. Results are further categorized per partition number 

3. Each partition results are hourly buckets in the ascending order. 

4. Value is oldest unacknowledged message age formatted in hours and minutes

transaction_events_metrics_400.description:
1.Tenant ID is missing or not an interger. 

2.Hours parameter value is invalid.

transaction_events_metrics_403.description:
Customer is not authorized to get transaction events metrics. 

This is a licensed feature, please contact Netskope support to purchase

transaction_events_token_200.description:
1.New customer authorized for transaction events, subscription key and path are generated for the first time. 

2.Existing customer authorized for transaction events, retrieving subscription key and path again.

transaction_events_token_400.description:
1.Tenant ID is missing or not an interger. 

2.Regenerate parameter value is invalid.

transaction_events_token_401.description:
Customer is not authorized to create/get subscription key and path. 

This is a licensed feature, please contact Netskope support to purchase

transaction_events_token_449.description:
1. Existing customer authorized for transaction events, subscription key and path were already downloaded. 

2.Use regenerate=true option to regenerate the subscription key. 

3.This is a one time step to onboard the existing customer to the API. 

4.Please start using the new subscription key as the existing key one has been invalidated.

throttleConfig.description: Control the throughput speed criteria of a retro scan.

timezone.description:
Used to calculate the explicit time ranges in these cases
1. For `dateFilter`, calculate exact time ranges from the relative
   date filter when required.
2. For `throttleConfig`, convert the user-defined schedule of the
   (day, hour) pairs from the `runningHours`.

violations.description: Number of entities found in violation of a policy. The map is keyed by policy id and the value is the violation count.

ScanTimeRange.description: Define a scan range with a set of UTC hours (24 hour format).

endDay.description: Indicate which day of the week to automatically pause the retroscan on. 0 is Monday, 6 is Sunday.

endHour.description: Indicate that the retroscan will automatically pause at the beginning of the defined hour.

startDay.description: Indicate which day of the week to start (or resume) the retroscan at. 0 is Monday, 6 is Sunday.

startHour.description: Indicate that the retroscan will automatically resume at the beginning of the defined hour.

ThrottleConfig.description: Define a relative throughput speed criteria.

runningHours.description: Define the running hours of a retro scan. If empty, the retro scan will always run. These (day, hour) pairs are expressed in the user timezone as set in the request body. The fractional hours are not supported; all times are whole hours relative to the user's timezone.

throttleValue.description: Define the throughput throttle value for a retro scan. A value of 0.50 means to run the retro scan at half speed (50%). If empty, the retro scan has a default throttle of 1 (no throttle).

TimestampRange.description: Define a half-open timestamp range [earliest, latest).

earliest.description: Epoch timestamp indicating only entities created/modified after or equal to the specified datetime will be scanned.

latest.description: Epoch timestamp indicating only entities created/modified before the specified datetime will be scanned.

Timezone.description: Define a timezone using a UTC offset.

timezoneID.description: Representation of the timezone in IANA format.

utcOffset.description: UTC offset in seconds. Must be between UTC-12:00 and UTC+14:00. For example, `-14400` represents UTC-4:00.
